thread.title: Rachel Lindsay will be the first black Bachelorette
thread.title_full: Rachel Lindsay will be the first black Bachelorette | Daily Mail Online

author: Dailymail Reporter
title: Rachel Lindsay will be the first black Bachelorette
text:
The popular ABC reality dating competition has cast its first ever black lead since it's inception back in 2002.
The Bachelor contestant Rachel Lindsay, who is currently vying for Nick Viall's heart, will be the next Bachelorette, according to The Hollywood Reporter .
While the star of the next cycle is usually announced once the current season has wrapped, the big announcement will be made weeks before the finale on Monday's Jimmy Kimmel Live!
Spoiler alert! The Bachelor contestant Rachel Lindsay, who is currently vying for Nick Viall's heart, is reported to be the next Bachelorette, according to The Hollywood Reporter
Lindsay, 31, still remains on the current season, which airs its next episode ahead of the official late night reveal, which will not only break race barriers but also inevitably spoil the finale.
The attorney from Dallas, Texas, who landed a one-on-one date with Nick in New Orleans, is one of the six remaining ladies heading into The Bachelor’s February 13 episode.
This is the first time that a Bachelor franchise series lead has been announced before the person’s elimination episode has aired.
Lindsay, 31, an attorney from Dallas, Texas, still remains on the current season, which airs its next episode ahead of the official announcement on Jimmy Kimmel Live! Monday night
Earlier today, The Bachelor creator Mike Fleiss teased on Twitter that something 'historic' would come Monday night
Earlier today, The Bachelor creator Mike Fleiss teased on Twitter that something 'historic' would come Monday night.
He tweeted: 'Tonite's the night!!! #thebachelor #historic.'
The Bachelor franchise has long endured criticism for the lack of diversity in casting contestants as well as the leads.
For more than 30 combined seasons an African-American man or woman has never held the main title.
This past summer, ABC president Channing Dungey - the first-ever African-American woman to head up a broadcast network - was asked by reporters at TCA about The Bachelor’s diversity problem.
Barrier-breaking: Lindsay was also the first black contestant to ever receive the coveted 'first impression' rose during the Bachelor and Bachelorette's 15 year run
To which Dungey replied: 'What we’d like to do is broaden that. We need to increase the pool of diverse candidates in the beginning. That is something we really want to put some effort and energy towards.'
To date, Nick’s season, which premiered last month, features the most diverse roundup of contestants with 22 white and eight non-white female contestants at the start of the cycle.
Lindsay was also the first black contestant to ever receive the coveted 'first impression' rose during the Bachelor and Bachelorette's 15 year run.
The Bachelor airs on ABC Monday at 8 pm E.T. and Jimmy Kimmel Live! will follow at 11:35 pm.
Diversity: Lindsay will be the first ever black lead since The Bachelor franchise's inception back in 2002
